children.name: what the value of sth is
value
children.definition: /ˈvæljuː/  the amount of money that something expensive, rare, or old would cost if it was sold - use this to talk about things like houses, cars, jewellery, paintings, or furniture:
examples: value of
▪ The value of the sculpture was estimated at $500,000.
increase/fall in value
▪ Some fine wines increase in value as they get older.
valuenounMONEYgiá trị (bằng tiền hoặc các hàng hoá khác mà có thể trao đổi được)
[ C or U ] the amount of money which can be received for something
_She had already sold everythingofvalue that she possessed.
_What is the valueofthe prize?
_The valueofthe poundfellagainst other European currencies yesterday.
_Property values have fallen since the plans for the airport were published.
_I thought the offer wasgoodvalue(for money)/US alsoa goodvalue (= a lot was offered for the amount of money paid) .

children.name: be worth
children.definition: /biː ˈwɜːʳθ/  if somethingis worth£1, £10, $100 etc, that is how much money it would cost if it was sold:
examples: ▪ How much is your ring worth?
be worth $500/£10 etc
▪ I guess their house must be worth about £500,000.
▪ That old piano can’t be worth more than $200.
worthadjectiveMONEY
having a particular value, especially in money
_Our house is worth £200 000.
_Heroin worth about $5 million was seized.

children.name: be valued at
children.definition: /biː ˈvæljuːd æt/  to have a particular value, especially a very high value which has been calculated:
examples: ▪ As a wedding present he gave her some pearls valued at $350,000.
▪ They have a classic car which has been valued at a higher price than they paid for it.
▪ At current market prices their holding in the company is valued at over $25 million.

children.name: ways of saying or asking how much sth costs
cost
children.definition: /kɒstǁkɔːst/  if something costs £10, $100 etc, that is what you have to pay in order to buy it:
examples: có giá
▪ How much does a house like that cost in America?
cost £10/$20/a lot etc
tốn 10 Bảng Anh / 20 Đô la / khá nhiều...
▪ Tickets for the show cost £15 or £20.
cost somebody £10/$20 etc
tốn ai đó 10 Bảng Anh / 20 Đô la
▪ I stayed in a hotel in Paris which cost me $150 a night.
cost a fortuneinformal cost a lot of money
rất đắt tiền
▪ Look at Frank’s new Mercedes - it must have cost a fortune.
it costs £10/$20/a lot etc to do something
Tốn 10 Bảng Anh / 20 Đô la / khá nhiều... để làm gì đó
▪ The Department of Education estimates that it will cost $17 billion to build the new schools.
costverb[ T ]MONEYgiá
cost,costIf something costs an amount of money, you must pay that amount to buy or do it
_"How much does this book cost (= What is the price of this book) ?" "It costs £25."
_Itcosts a lottobuy a house in this part of London.
_[ + two objects ]The trip will cost you $1000.

children.name: how much
children.definition: /ˌhaʊ ˈmʌtʃ/ spokensay how much toaskwhat the price or cost of something is:

children.name: bao nhiêu ( hỏi )
examples: ▪ That’s a beautiful rug -- how much did you pay for it?
▪ By the way, how much does it cost to use the swimming pool?

children.name: be U
children.definition: be/bi strong biː/  if something is £100, $1000 etc, that is how much it costs - use this especially when you are asking or replying to a question about the cost of something:
examples: có giá ( hỏi , đáp)
▪ ‘I like your new shirt - how much was it?’ ‘It was only fifteen pounds.’
▪ I can’t remember how much the flight cost. I think it was around $400.

children.name: at a cost of
children.definition: /ət ə ˈkɒst ɒvǁ-ˈkɔːst-/  if something is done, sold etc at a cost of a particular amount, that is how much it costs - used especially in news reports: có mức giá
examples: ▪ Surveys are being conducted in 10 European States at a cost of £50 million.

children.name: set sb back
children.definition: if something that you buy sets you back a particular amount of money, usually a large amount, that is how much it costs, especially when you think that it is very expensive: Tốn ai đó khá nhiều tiền

children.name: set sb back £200/$400 etc
examples: ▪ A good quality saxophone will set you back at least £1000.

children.name: set sb back
examples: ▪ If she’s hoping to buy a new sportscar, it’s going to really set her back!

children.name: be priced at
children.definition: /biː ˈpraɪst æt/  if a product is priced at a particular price that is how much the person who makes or sells it has decided it should cost:

children.name: được định giá
examples: ▪ The book, which is priced at £38, will be available in the shops from September.
▪ I watched a demonstration of their new cordless phone, priced at $350.

children.name: sell for
children.definition: /go for/ˈsel fɔːʳ, ˈgəʊ fɔːʳ/  to cost a particular amount of money - use this especially when you think this is more than it is worth:
examples: được bán với giá
sell for £400/$600 etc
đượcbán với giá 400 Bảng Anh/ 600 Đô la/...
▪ Clothes with designer labels sell for ridiculous prices nowadays.
▪ Houses in this area are selling for over $400,000.
go for £100/$250 etc
đượcbán với giá 100 Bảng Anh/ 250 Đô la/...
▪ Watches like that are going for about £15 in the market.
go to somebody for £100/$250 etc
vào tay ai đó với giá 100 Bảng Anh/ 250 Đô la/...
▪ The painting finally went to a private collector for $60 million.

children.name: fetch
children.partOfSpeech: [transitive verb not in progressive or passive]
children.definition: /fetʃ/  if something fetches a particular price, it is sold for that price or someone receives that amount of money by selling it, especially at a public sale: bán được với giá

children.name: fetch £40/$500 etc
examples: ▪ It’s a very old car, but I’m still hoping it’ll fetch around £200.
▪ Van Gogh’s "Sunflowers’ was expected to fetch more than $20 million.

children.name: what’s the damage
children.definition: /ˌwɒts ðə ˈdæmɪdʒ/ British spoken use this to ask what the total cost of something is, especially a job someone has already done for you or something you have already received:
examples: Hết bao nhiêu?

children.name: ▪ ‘The mechanic’s just about finished working on your car, sir.’ ‘Thanks, and what’s the damage?’
what you have to pay for sth
cost
children.definition: the amount of money you have to pay for services, activities, or things you need all the time such as food and electricity.Costis usually used when talking in a general way about whether something is expensive or cheap rather than when talking about exact prices :
examples: We’ll make sure you have the operation, whatever the cost.
cost of
the cost of accommodation
at a cost of
The new building’s going upat a cost of$82 million.
at no extra costwithout having to pay more
We will deliver and install your computer at no extra cost.
A cassette/radio is includedat no extra cost.
RegisterIn everyday English, people usually askhow much did it cost?orhow much was it?rather than using the nouncost:
What was thecostof the accommodation?➔How muchdid the accommodationcost? | I’ll find out thecost.➔I’ll find outhow muchitcosts/is.
high/lowthe high cost of fuel

children.name: pay the cost of something
examples: I’m not sure how I’m going to pay the cost of going to college.

children.name: cover the cost
children.definition: pay for something
examples: The money he had saved just covered the cost of the trip.

children.name: meet/bear the cost of something
children.definition: pay for something, especially with difficulty
examples: His family were unable to meet the cost of his operation.

children.name: afford the cost of something
examples: We can’t afford the cost of a holiday abroad this year.

children.name: reduce/lower/bring down the cost
examples: If you go later in the year, it will bring down the cost of your holiday.

children.name: cut the cost
children.definition: reduce it
examples: The government has promised to cut the cost of medical care.

children.name: increase/push up the cost
examples: The new tax will increase the cost of owning a car.

children.name: the cost rises/goes up
examples: The cost of electricity has risen again.

children.name: the cost falls/goes down
examples: Airline costs have fallen considerably.

children.name: the average cost
examples: What’s the average cost of a wedding in the UK?

children.name: an extra/additional cost
examples: At the campsite, many activities are available at no extra cost.

children.name: the full/total cost
examples: Experts are still assessing the full cost of the disaster.

children.name: the estimated cost
children.definition: one that is guessed and may not be exact
examples: The estimated cost was in the region of £3,000.

children.name: the annual/monthly cost
examples: This figure represents the annual cost of a loan.

children.name: labour/production/transport etc costs
examples: They had to pay £30,000 in legal costs.

children.name: running/operating costs
children.definition: the amount it costs to run a business, a machine etc
examples: The new technology is cheaper and the running costs are lower.

children.name: borrowing costs
children.definition: the amount it costs to borrow money from a bank
examples: Interest rates and borrowing costs are likely to be higher next year.

children.name: the cost of living
children.definition: the amount you need to pay for food, clothes etc
examples: People are complaining about the rising cost of living.

children.name: price
children.definition: the amount of money you have to pay for something that is for sale, especially in a shop:
examples: They sell good-quality clothes at reasonable prices.
COMMON ERRORS
►Do not say 'a convenient price'. Saya reasonable priceora fair price.

children.name: high
examples: House prices in the UK are very high.

children.name: low
examples: With such low prices, there are lots of eager buyers.

children.name: reasonable
children.definition: not too high
examples: The price was reasonable for such good food.

children.name: fair
examples: I am sure we can agree on a fair price.

children.name: astronomical
children.definition: extremely high
examples: Many fans paid astronomical prices for their tickets.

children.name: exorbitant/extortionate
children.definition: much too high
examples: £10,000 seemed an exorbitant price for the rug.

children.name: inflated
children.definition: higher than is usual or reasonable
examples: People seem willing to pay inflated prices for houses in central London.

children.name: house/food/oil etc prices
examples: A poor harvest led to higher food prices.

children.name: a good price
children.definition: quite high
examples: Did you get a good price for your car?

children.name: a bargain price
children.definition: alsoa knockdown/giveaway price
examples: (= much lower than usual )We sell quality cars at bargain prices.|The house is available at a knockdown price of $195,000.

children.name: the market price
children.definition: the price of something on a market at a particular time
examples: We think the stock’s current market price is too high.

children.name: the asking price
children.definition: the amount of money that someone is asking for when they are selling something, especially a house
examples: The property is worth more than the asking price.

children.name: the purchase priceformal
children.definition: the price that someone pays when they buy something, especially a house
examples: You can obtain a loan for up to 90% of the purchase price.

children.name: the retail price
children.definition: the price that the public pays for something in a shop
examples: Tax is 40% of the retail price of a typical bottle of wine.

children.name: the wholesale price
children.definition: the price that a business such as a shop pays to buy something
examples: Wholesale coffee prices have fallen.

children.name: a price goes up/rises/increases
examples: When supplies go down, prices tend to go up.

children.name: a price goes down/falls/decreases
examples: In real terms, the price of clothes has fallen over the last ten years.

children.name: a price shoots up/soars/rockets
children.definition: increases quickly by a large amount
examples: The price of oil soared in the 1970s.

children.name: prices fluctuate
children.definition: keep going up and down
examples: Gas prices have continued to fluctuate in recent months.

children.name: prices start from £200/$300 etc
examples: Ticket prices start from £39.00.

children.name: prices range from £30 to £65 etc
examples: Over 1,000 paintings will be shown with prices ranging from £50 to £5,000.

children.name: put up/increase/raise a price
examples: Manufacturers have had to put their prices up.

children.name: cut/lower/reduce a price
examples: The company recently cut the price of its best-selling car.

children.name: slash a price
children.definition: reduce it by a very large amount
examples: Many carpet stores have slashed prices to bring in customers.

children.name: fix a price
children.definition: decide on it, sometimes illegally with others
examples: Publishers are not permitted to fix prices with one another.

children.name: agree on a price
examples: Now all we need to do is agree on a price.

children.name: pay a good/low etc price
examples: I paid a very reasonable price for my guitar.

children.name: get a good/reasonable etc price
children.definition: be paid a particular amount for something
examples: Farmers now get a decent price for their crop.

children.name: fetch a good/high etc priceBritish English,bring a good, high etc priceAmerican English
children.definition: be sold for a particular amount of money
examples: I’m sure the painting would fetch a good price in London.

children.name: a price rise/increase
examples: Consumers are facing more fuel price rises.

children.name: a price cut/reduction
examples: Holiday sales were down, even with drastic price cuts.

children.name: a price freeze
children.definition: when prices are kept at the same level by a company or by the government
examples: A price freeze on nine basic goods was announced on June 14.

children.name: a fall/drop in prices
examples: Poor demand led to a sharp drop in prices.

children.name: a rise in prices
examples: The sharp rise in wholesale food prices will have to be passed onto customers.

children.name: in/outside sb’s price range
children.definition: used when saying that someone can/cannot afford to pay for something
examples: Unfortunately, there was nothing in our price range.

children.name: price of
examples: The price of fuel keeps going up.

children.name: price for
examples: We agreed a price for the bike.
Supermarkets often offer you two products for the price of one.

children.name: half pricehalf the usual price
examples: I bought these jeans half price in a sale.

children.name: charge
children.definition: the amount of money that you pay for a service, or for being allowed to use sth: phí
examples: charge of
an admission charge of $5
charge for
There is a charge for the use of the swimming pool.
at no charge
Guided tours are providedat no charge.
at no extra chargewithout having to pay more
Members and their guests are welcome to use the club’s facilities at no extra charge.

children.name: a small charge
examples: For a small charge guests can use the hotel sauna.

children.name: an extra/additional charge
examples: Breakfast may be served in your bedroom at no extra charge.

children.name: free of charge
children.definition: with no cost
examples: Delivery is free of charge.

children.name: sb’s charges are high/low
children.definition: you have to pay a lot/a little
examples: His charges are too high.

children.name: a fixed charge
examples: There’s a fixed charge for having a dental check.

children.name: a nominal charge
children.definition: a very small amount of money
examples: You can use the tennis courts for a nominal charge.

children.name: a minimum charge
children.definition: an amount that is the least you can pay
examples: There’s a minimum charge of £10 per person in the Terrace restaurant.

children.name: a service charge
children.definition: for service in a hotel, restaurant etc
examples: The restaurant’s prices include a 10% service charge.

children.name: an admission charge
children.definition: for being allowed to enter a place
examples: There is no admission charge.

children.name: a call-out chargeBritish English
children.definition: that you must pay a workman to come to your home
examples: The electrician said there is a £40 call-out charge.

children.name: a cancellation charge
examples: If you change your flight booking, you may have to pay a cancellation charge.

children.name: a delivery charge
examples: How much is the store’s delivery charge?

children.name: bank charges
children.definition: fees charged by a bank for some services
examples: You will have to pay bank charges if your account is overdrawn.

children.name: pay a charge
examples: There will be a small charge to pay.

children.name: make a charge
children.definition: ask you to pay a charge
examples: We make no charge for this service.

children.name: incur a chargeformal
children.definition: result in you paying a charge
examples: All cancellations incur a charge.

children.name: introduce/impose a charge
examples: The government introduced a charge for water.

children.name: waive a charge
children.definition: allow you not to pay it
examples: I’ve asked the bank to waive the charge this time.

children.name: fee
children.definition: the amount you have to pay to enter a place or join a group, or for the services of a professional person such as a lawyer or a doctor :
examples: There is no entrance fee.
The membership fee is £125 a year
fee of
Some actors can ask a fee of around $1,000,000 a movie.
You can use the gym and pool for a fee of £35 a month.

children.name: small/low
examples: Some companies will sell the items for you, for a small fee.

children.name: high/large/big
examples: The school fees are extremely high.

children.name: a hefty/fat feeinformal
children.definition: a very large fee
examples: Customers are being charged a hefty fee for their telephone service.

children.name: an annual/a monthly fee
examples: An annual fee of £150 has been introduced.

children.name: an entrance/entry fee
children.definition: a fee to enter a place
examples: The gallery charges an entrance fee.

children.name: a membership fee
children.definition: a fee to become a member of a club or organization
examples: The gym’s yearly membership fee is £250.

children.name: a subscription fee
children.definition: a fee to receive copies of a newspaper or magazine
examples: You can pay the subscription fee by cheque.

children.name: school/college/university fees
examples: She paid for her college fees by taking a part-time job as a waitress.

children.name: tuition fees
children.definition: money paid for being taught
examples: Many universities now charge tuition fees for these courses.

children.name: doctor’s/lawyer’s/accountant’s etc fees
examples: We need to find the money for the doctor’s fees somehow.

children.name: legal/medical fees
examples: She received £300 compensation after legal fees had been deducted.

children.name: a flat/fixed/set fee
children.definition: a fee that is the same in every case
examples: You pay a flat fee for all the services that are provided.

children.name: a booking fee
children.definition: alsoa service feeAmerican English
examples: (= a charge you pay when buying a ticket )Tickets for the concert are £45, plus a booking fee.

children.name: a cancellation fee
children.definition: a charge for ending an agreement you have made to travel on a train, stay at a hotel etc
examples: A 10% cancellation fee will be charged if the booking is cancelled.

children.name: a licence feeBritish English
children.definition: the money a television licence costs
examples: The licence fee is set to rise again.

children.name: charge a fee
examples: The accountant charged a big fee for his services.

children.name: pay a fee
examples: You have to pay a small fee to rent a locker.

children.name: rate
children.definition: /reɪt/  the usual cost of a service or job:
examples: ▪ We are able to offer a whole range of services at very reasonable rates.
hourly/weekly/daily rate
▪ Our shop assistants are paid an hourly rate of £5.50
the going rate: the rate that people are willing to pay at the present time
▪ £150 is the going rate for tickets for the concert.
fixed rateone that is always the same
▪ There is a fixed rate for the job, regardless of how long it takes.
ratenoun[ C ]PAYMENT
an amount or level of payment
_We agreed a rate with the painter before he started work.
_What's thegoing(= standard) rateforthis type of work?
_Do you pay your mortgage on afixedorvariablerate?

children.name: fare
children.definition: /feəʳ/  the cost of a journey on a bus, train, plane etc:
examples: Giá vé
▪ I had to walk home because I didn’t have enough money for the fare.
coach/train/air etc fare
Giá vé xe đò/xe lửa/máy bay
▪ How much is the train fare from Toronto to Montreal?
▪ A one-week stay in Majorca costs $779 including air fare.
fare increases
Việc tăng giá vé
▪ The biggest fare increases were on the Kansas City to Minneapolis line.
farenounPAYMENTtiền xe;tiền đò;tiền phà; tiền vé
[ C ] the money that you pay for a journey on a vehicle such as a bus or train
_Train fares are going up again.

children.name: toll
children.definition: money that you have to pay in order to drive over some bridges or roads: thuế qua cầu/đường
examples: ▪ You have to pay tolls on many of the major roads in France.
toll bridge/road/laneone that you have to pay to use
▪ In 1871 they built a toll bridge from the mainland to the island.
tollnounCHARGE tiền trả cho việc sử dụng cầu/đường; lệ phí cầu đường
[ C ] a small amount of money that you have to pay to use a road, cross a bridge, etc
_He's just got a job collecting tolls at the start of the motorway.

children.name: admission
children.definition: nounALLOW INtiền phải trả để được vào nơi công cộng, tiền vào cửa
examples: [ C or U ] when someone is given permission to enter
a place, or the money that you pay to enter a place
_Admissiontothe exhibition will be by invitation only.
_How much do theycharge foradmission.
_The admissioncharge/feeis £2.
_There's a notice outside the building which says 'No admission before 12 noon'.

children.name: costs
children.definition: the money that a person or organization has to spendregularlyon heating, rent, electricity etc: chi phí
examples: ▪ What are your annual fuel costs?
running coststhe cost of owning and using something
I’m looking for a car with low running costs.
Because of the engine’s efficiency the car has very lowrunning costs
reduce/cut costs
▪ Falling sales have forced companies to cut costs.
We have to cut costs in order to remain competitive.
At this rate we’ll barelycoverourcosts(= make enough money to pay for the things we have bought ).
the travelcosts incurredin attending the meeting(= money you have to spend )

children.name: spending
children.definition: /expenditureC2  the amount of money that is spent, especially by a government or other organization:chi tiêu, phí tổn
examples: ▪ The government intends to cut its expenditure by 10% next year.

children.name: public spending/expenditureby a government
examples: ▪ The answer to inadequate health care is to increase public spending, not reduce it.

children.name: spending/expenditure on
examples: ▪ Company spending on staff benefits has been cut dramatically in recent years.

children.name: outgoings
children.definition: /ˈaʊtˌgəʊɪŋz/  the amount of money that someone has to spend regularly on rent, bills, food etc for their home or business:

children.name: chi phí
examples: ▪ The outgoings on a house this size are very high.
▪ I wrote a check for $200 to cover various outgoings.

children.name: outlay
children.definition: /ˈaʊtleɪ/  the amount of money that someone must spend when theyfirst starta new business or activity:

children.name: kinh phí
examples: ▪ The best business is one with a small outlay and with no risk involved.

children.name: outlay on
examples: ▪ When we built the factory the outlay on machinery was heavy but we were able to buy all the latest equipment.

children.name: initial outlayoutlay in the beginning
examples: ▪ T- shirts are easy to produce, requiring little initial outlay and a minimum of time and effort.

children.name: expenses
children.definition: the money that you spend on things that you need, for example on food, rent, and travel:chi tiêu phí tổn
examples: ▪ John and Rachel have a new baby, so they have a lot of expenses right now.

children.name: travel/living/medical etc expenses
examples: ▪ Living expenses are much higher in London.
▪ The company doesn’t pay my travel expenses.

children.name: overheads
children.definition: British /overheadAmerican /ˈəʊvəʳhed(z)/  the amount of money that acompanyor abusinesspersonhas to spend on rent, their workers’ pay, office furniture etc:

children.name: tổng phí
examples: ▪ The cost of the movie was high because of the large production overhead.
▪ The company’s overheads were much lower this year owing to the closure of several offices nationwide.
▪ Restaurant prices have been put up to cover the ever-increasing overheads.

children.name: cost
children.definition: sth that you lose, give away, damage etc in order to achieve something :cái giá phải trả

children.name: at (a) cost to sb
examples: She had kept her promise to Christine, but at what cost to herself?

children.name: social/environmental etc cost
examples: They need to weigh up thecosts and benefits(= disadvantages and advantages )of regulation.
He’s determined to win,whatever the cost(= no matter how much work, money, risk etc is needed ).
We must avoid a scandalat all costs(= whatever happens ).

children.name: upkeep
children.definition: /ˈʌpkiːp/  the continuousprocessandcostinvolved in keeping something in good condition, especially a building or garden: bảo dưỡng
examples: the upkeep of sth
▪ The trustees are responsible for the upkeep of the bridge.
▪ The Council’s contribution towards the upkeep of the church is very much appreciated.
▪ You get more for your money if you buy an old house, but upkeep costs will be higher
upkeepnoun[ U ]chi phí bảo dưỡng, chi phí sửa sang, chi phí bảo quản
the cost of keeping something, such as a building, in good condition
_The upkeepoflarger old properties is very expensive.
_Council employees are responsible for the upkeepofthe gardens.

children.name: price
children.definition: the unpleasant results that you must accept or experience for getting or doing something: cái giá
examples: An extra few minutes at the airport is a small price to pay for safe travel.

children.name: pay a price
children.definition: suffer
examples: We paid a heavy price for our mistakes this season.

children.name: come at a price
children.definition: alsocome at a high price
examples: (= involve suffering or a bad result )She won fame, but it came at a high price.

children.name: exact a priceformal
children.definition: make someone suffer
examples: The success of the nation’s businesses has exacted a dreadful price from the people.

children.name: a high price
examples: Smokers often pay a high price in terms of their health.

children.name: a heavy price
examples: Any country breaking international law will be made to pay a heavy price.

children.name: a terrible price
examples: The sport can exact a terrible price from its participants.

children.name: something is a small price to pay
children.definition: something is worth suffering in order to achieve something more important
examples: Changing his job would be a small price to pay to keep his marriage intact.

children.name: price of
examples: He’s never at home, but that’s the price of success.
She was finally made senior executive, butat what price!

children.name: expense
children.definition: noun sựchitiêu; phí tổn; tiền đểmua hoặclàm gì

children.name: service
children.definition: nounDEALING WITH CUSTOMER

children.name: quotation
children.definition: /quoteinformal  a written statement of exactly how much money something will cost, especially a service: bảng báo giá
examples: ▪ Get a few quotations from different firms so that you can compare prices.
quotationnoun[ C ] (informalquote)PRICE báo giá
the price that a person says they will charge to do a piece of work
_I asked several builders togiveme a quote for the work.
